docs.lead_paragraph: A doctor calls it unethical to sell cigarettes that kill along with medicines that save lives.
docs.snippet: A doctor calls it unethical to sell cigarettes that kill along with medicines that save lives.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. de Duve, a Belgian biochemist whose discoveries shed light on genetic disorders like Tay-Sachs disease, shared the 1974 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine with two others.

headline.seo: Christian de Duve, Nobel-Winning Biochemist, Dies at 95
headline.main: Christian de Duve, 95, Dies; Nobel-Winning Biochemist
headline.print_headline: Christian de Duve, 95, Dies; Nobel-Winning Biochemist

docs.abstract: Dr Christian de Duve, a Belgian biochemist whose discoveries about the internal workings of cells shed light on genetic disorders that helped give birth to the field of modern cell biology, earning him a Nobel Prize, dies at age 95.
docs.snippet: Dr. de Duve, a Belgian biochemist whose discoveries shed light on genetic disorders like Tay-Sachs disease, shared the 1974 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine with two others.

docs.lead_paragraph: An irascible but modest scientist devoted his life to preventing childhood illnesses, with such success that their once-fearsome toll has faded from consciousness.

headline.seo: Maurice Hilleman, M.M.R. Vaccine’s Forgotten Hero

docs.abstract: Maurice R Hilleman, scientist at Merck in the 1960s, devoted his life to preventing childhood illnesses, with such success that their once-fearsome toll has faded from consciousness; Hilleman devised or improved over 25 vaccines, and many researchers credit him with having saved more lives than any other scientist in 20th century.
docs.snippet: An irascible but modest scientist devoted his life to preventing childhood illnesses, with such success that their once-fearsome toll has faded from consciousness.

headline.main: Low-Risk Skin Cancers Often Treated Too Aggressively in Elderly, Study Finds

docs.abstract: For the elderly, not only can even supposedly minor procedures have complications, but the cancers grow so slowly that they’re unlikely to cause problems in the patients’ remaining years.
docs.snippet: For the elderly, not only can even supposedly minor procedures have complications, but the cancers grow so slowly that they’re unlikely to cause problems in the patients’ remaining years.

docs.lead_paragraph: An outbreak of avian flu in Asia raises questions about national preparedness for pandemics. A reward system for medical innovators would be a step in the right direction, an economist says.
docs.abstract: Tyler Cowen Economic View contends that outbreak of avian flu in Asia raises questions about national preparedness for pandemics; notes view of economists who say that reward system for medical innovators would be a step in the right direction.
docs.snippet: An outbreak of avian flu in Asia raises questions about national preparedness for pandemics. A reward system for medical innovators would be a step in the right direction, an economist says.

docs.lead_paragraph: LAFER--Fred. Columbia University Medical Center mourns the passing of our friend Fred Lafer, whose counsel and wisdom as President of the Henry and Marilyn Taub Foundation allowed us to establish The Taub Institute for Research on Alzheimer's Disease and the Aging Brain. His ongoing advocacy, critical mind, and friendship helped ensure that the work of the Taub Institute continues to thrive, as we seek better understanding and treatment for age-related brain diseases. All of us at Columbia extend our condolences to his wife, Barbara; daughters Diana and Deborah; son, Gordon; and the extended Taub family. Lee Goldman, MD Dean of the Faculties of Health Sciences and Medicine and Executive Vice President, Columbia University Richard Mayeux, MD, MSc Gertrude H. Sergievsky Professor of Neurology, Psychiatry & Epidemiology Chairman, Department of Neurology Co-Director, Taub Institute Michael L. Shelanski, MD, PhD Delafield Professor and Chairman Department of Pathology & Cell Biology Director, Medical Scientist Training Program Co-Director, Taub Institute
docs.snippet: LAFER--Fred. Columbia University Medical Center mourns the passing of our friend Fred Lafer, whose counsel and wisdom as President of the Henry and Marilyn Taub Foundation allowed us to establish The Taub Institute for Research on Alzheimer's Disease...

docs.lead_paragraph: In “Saving Normal,” and “Book of Woe,” a psychiatrist and psychotherapist caution against a surfeit of diagnoses in their profession’s ever-expanding official manual.

headline.seo: Greenberg’s ‘Book of Woe’ and Frances’s ‘Saving Normal’
headline.main: Two Pleas for Sanity in Judging Saneness
headline.print_headline: Two Pleas For Sanity In Judging Saneness

docs.abstract: Dwight Garner reviews books The Book of Woe: The DSM and the Unmaking of Psychiatry by Gary Greenberg and Saving Normal: An Insider's Revolt Against Out-of-Control Psychiatric Diagnosis, DSM-5, Big Pharma, and the Medicalization of Ordinary Life by Allen Frances.
docs.snippet: In “Saving Normal,” and “Book of Woe,” a psychiatrist and psychotherapist caution against a surfeit of diagnoses in their profession’s ever-expanding official manual.

keywords.value: Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (Book)
keywords.name: creative_works

His ongoing advocacy, critical mind, and friendship helped ensure that the work of the Taub Institute continues to thrive, as we seek better understanding and treatment for age-related brain diseases. docs.lead_paragraph: The story behind the approval of Procysbi, a new treatment, is an example of the important role that determined parents and disease foundations can play in supporting drug development.

headline.seo: F.D.A. Approves Raptor Drug for Form of Cystinosis
headline.main: Parental Quest Bears Fruit in a Kidney Disease Treatment
headline.print_headline: A Rare Ailment and a High Price

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration approves drug Procysbi to treat nephropathic cystinosis, extremely rare inherited disease that, if untreated, typically destroys the kidneys by age 10; to be sold by Raptor Pharmaceutical Corp, drug was developed with early financing from a foundation that shows the important role that determined parents can play in drug development, but also raises questions about whether society can afford to pay for drugs that treat rare illnesses.
docs.snippet: The story behind the approval of Procysbi, a new treatment, is an example of the important role that determined parents and disease foundations can play in supporting drug development.
